title: 113_hr901
content: The Tax Return Due Date Simplification and Modernization Act of 2013 establishes new due dates for partnership Form 1065, S Corporation Form 1120S, and C Corporation Form 1120. The Tax Return Due Date Simplification and Modernization Act of 2013 sets new filing deadlines for partnership and S Corporation tax returns. Partnerships must file by March 15 for calendar year basis and the 15th day of the third month for fiscal year basis. S Corporations must also adhere to new deadlines for filing. The Tax Return Due Date Simplification and Modernization Act of 2013 changes filing deadlines for partnership and S Corporation tax returns. Partnerships must file by March 31 for calendar year basis and the last day of the third month for fiscal year basis. Amendments include changing deadlines from the 15th to the last day and adjusting time frames. Section 1362(d)(1)(C)(ii) is amended to change the deadline from the 15th day to the last day of the 3rd month. Conforming amendments for C Corporations also change deadlines from the 3rd month to the 4th month in various sections. The deadline for certain tax returns is changed from the 3rd month to the 4th month starting in 2014. SEC. 3. Modification of due dates by regulation. The Secretary of the Treasury will adjust regulations for tax returns starting after December 31, 2013. Extensions for partnership returns (Form 1065) will be up to 6 months, for trusts and estates (Form 1041) up to 5.5 months, and for employee benefit plans (Form 5500) an automatic 3.5 months. Extensions for exempt organizations' Forms 990 will also be modified. The maximum extension for tax returns of exempt organizations, trusts, and Black Lung Benefit Trusts is an automatic 6-month period after the filing deadline. The due dates and maximum extensions for various tax forms are specified, such as Form 8870, Form 3520-A, and Form TD F 90-22.1. The extensions range from 6 months after the filing deadline to specific dates like April 15th. Taxpayers filing Form 3520 can request an automatic 6-month extension separately from their income tax return. Penalties for failure to timely request or file an extension may be waived by the Secretary. Section 4 allows corporations to automatically extend their income tax returns by 6 months instead of 3 months, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2013.
